metadata.synopsis: Emperor talks to player after they leave House of Hope.All Emperor lines are telepathic.
metadata.how_to_trigger: 1. CTY_Main_A2. Visit House of Hope3. Kill Raphael4. Go out

36.speaker: Lae'zel
36.text: You slaughtered a devil in his own home, and returned empty-handed? You've made better decisions.
36.context: NodeContext: All Emperor lines in this scene, telepathic.

59.speaker: Lae'zel
59.text: A curious thing - to enter into a devil's home, and make it out alive.
59.context: NodeContext: All Emperor lines in this scene, telepathic.

16.text: I trust you saw the error of your ways. Do not err again.

69.text: So you wormed your way into the devil's lair.
69.context: NodeContext: All Emperor lines in this scene, telepathic.

17.text: All to steal the Orphic Hammer.

8.text: I hope your ambitions end there.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: I have already told you that the githyanki prince only wants to see you dead. But it seems you still do not trust me.

27.text: I have already told you that the githyanki prince only wants to see you dead. But it seems you still do not trust me.

56.speaker: Lae'zel
56.text: Open the Prism. I trust Gith's heir over a wretched ghaik.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Let me into the Prism. I trust Gith's heir over a wretched ghaik.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: I do trust you. I just like to have insurance.

57.text: That is not my definition of trust.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: You're a mind flayer. Can you blame me for not trusting you?

33.text: His domination is what keeps you free. You know this already.

21.text: Still, you would test our alliance.

40.text: You are falling into the same trap as the Chosen.

53.text: Their distrust of one another is their undoing.

58.text: We must not make the same mistake. We must work together.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: I'll work with you, but I'll never trust you.

63.text: Nonetheless, our fates are bound. And in the absence of a happier union, I will accept a useful one.

73.text: You may think yourself ingenious for having slain a devil.

22.text: But you have merely ironed out a wrinkle.

76.text: The elder brain will not be such an easy foe.

82.text: It is time we resume our journey to find it.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: I promise I won't use the hammer.

68.text: I wish I could trust you, but that you felt you needed to have it at all tells me that you are not worthy of that trust.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: I never asked to be stuck with you.

67.text: I could say the same of you.

5.speaker: Player
5.text: Be that as it may, Orpheus deserves to be free.

79.text: When he wakens from his incarceration, what do you think he will make of you? The one who bears the spawn his very nature bends him to revile?

15.text: And even if you survived him, what of the elder brain? Without the protection I leverage for you, you would be enthralled in an instant.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: All right. You've made your point.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: I'll find another way to survive. One that doesn't involve abusing a githyanki.

61.text: Careful. You will make a mind flayer laugh.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: So you keep saying, but why should I believe you?

9.text: Act upon your disbelief, and you will not even live to regret your actions.

72.text: And destroyed the contract that bound you.

30.text: The contract you tried to hide from me.

0.text: Did you think I wouldn't find out?

32.text: Did you think that you would quietly infiltrate the devil's home with me nestled right within your thoughts, and mask your true intentions from me?

65.text: The contract you never should have signed.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: I regretted it the moment I signed it.

60.text: Good. Then you did the right thing by destroying it.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: I destroyed it. You should be happy.

2.text: You realised the error of your ways, and corrected them.

42.text: But you would do better not to err in the first place. Especially when there is so much at stake.

18.text: You saw for yourself what the Chosen are capable of.

24.text: But did you also see their weakness?

28.text: Yes, in a manner of speaking.

71.text: It was their union that made them.

51.text: They had an almost flawless plan to dominate Faerûn. But their distrust is their undoing.

81.text: We must not fall into the same trap. We must trust one another.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: Fine. From now on, I trust you.

20.text: Good. If we can count upon each other, then we may count one advantage in our favour.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: I was curious. I wanted to understand what the devil had to offer.

29.text: There is only one thing to understand about a devil - it serves only itself. Anything it promised to deliver, it would recover tenfold.
